header_summary:
A new effort to consolidate Bitcoin developers' opinions on covenant proposals has been launched, seeking to facilitate consensus for upcoming soft forks by creating a draft for a Bitcoin wiki page. This initiative, similar to the approach taken with the SegWit support page, encourages developers to contribute by adding opcodes and sharing insights, with a special focus on enhancing pools with covenants through proposals like OP_CheckTemplateVerify, detailed at [Rationale for OP_CTV](https://notes.dunst.be/slide//2/slide/view/Ekky-cAegV9dSOaNOjH9TStNOmAnrhDDc9hxHlmRs5M/embed/present/) ([Bitcoin Wiki](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Covenants_support)).

sCrypt and StarkWare have demonstrated a bridge covenant on Bitcoin, showcasing a potential production-grade bridge to the Starknet Layer 2 network. This bridge employs a recursive covenant Bitcoin script for smart contract functionality and uses a Merkle tree for efficient state and transaction management, with the entire codebase available at [GitHub](https://github.com/Bitcoin-Wildlife-Sanctuary/scrypt-poc-bridge). This proof-of-concept underscores the technical capabilities for enhancing Bitcoin's interoperability with Layer 2 networks.

Discussions in the blockchain community have raised concerns over the economic impact of blockchain reorganizations, especially those extending beyond six blocks, and have questioned the practical utility of features designed to exploit block validation competitions due to their rarity and potential consequences ([source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/can-parallel-validation-side-step-the-slow-block-issue/1288/10)). Additionally, experimentation with replacement cycling using Warnet has been revisited, highlighting developments in deploying lightning nodes and implementing a new plugin system to enhance user accessibility and functionality customization ([Warnet Pull Request 422](https://github.com/bitcoin-dev-project/warnet/pull/422), [Warnet Pull Request 373](https://github.com/bitcoin-dev-project/warnet/pull/373)).

recent_posts.title: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
recent_posts.summary:
- A new initiative seeks Bitcoin developers' opinions on covenant proposals for consensus building.
- The effort includes creating a Bitcoin wiki page, similar to the SegWit support page, for developer contributions.
- Highlighting the OP_CTV proposal's significance, developers are encouraged to refine soft fork proposals collaboratively.

recent_posts.title: Implementing a Bridge Covenant on OP_CAT-Enabled Bitcoin: A Proof of Concept
recent_posts.summary:
- A collaborative bridge between Bitcoin and Starknet Layer 2 was created by sCrypt and StarkWare.
- The bridge uses batched transactions and a Merkle tree for secure, efficient state updates.
- The proof-of-concept bridge's code, including tests, is available on GitHub for developer contributions.

recent_posts.title: Can parallel validation side-step the slow block issue?
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses the economic effects of deep blockchain reorganizations.
- It questions the efficacy of block validation competitions in improving blockchain performance.
- Concerns are raised about the rarity and impact of such competitive validation scenarios.

recent_posts.title: OP_EXPIRE: Mitigating replacing cycling attacks
recent_posts.summary:
- Jonas mentioned a significant refactor in Warnet's replacement cycling experiments.
- A new system for deploying lightning nodes into Warnet is in development.
- A user-friendly plugin system is being designed to simplify functionality enhancements.

active_posts.title: ColliderScript: Covenants in Bitcoin via 160-bit hash collisions
active_posts.summary:
- The team's method enables creating Bitcoin covenants without soft forks using Tapscript.
- It introduces significant computational costs, suggesting the need for specialized ASICs for practical use.
- This innovation allows for arbitrary computation within Bitcoin transactions, potentially enhancing quantum resistance.

active_posts.title: Un-FE’d Covenants: Char-ting a new path to Emulated Covenants via BitVM Integrity Checks
active_posts.summary:
- The email introduces a new method for Bitcoin covenants without altering the protocol.
- It features covenant emulators and signing servers, requiring oracle signers to deposit bonds.
- Detailed explanations and the framework are available in a paper online for further study.

active_posts.title: Slashing covenants
active_posts.summary:
- Slashing covenants provide a new way to enforce Bitcoin transaction rules by penalizing rule violations.
- They function without new cryptographic assumptions, using Bitcoin's script and Lamport signatures for enforcement.
- Despite being less secure than some methods, they offer efficiency and compatibility with existing Bitcoin infrastructure.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal examines Bitcoin's vulnerabilities, suggesting improvements for network security and efficiency.
- It proposes solutions for the timewarp vulnerability and issues with non-SegWit transactions to improve stability.
- Community involvement is encouraged to tackle bugs and inefficiencies, though some suggestions like reducing block size are contentious.

active_posts.title: Libbitcoin for Core people
active_posts.summary:
- Eric Voskuil noted Libbitcoin's IBD is up to 15 times faster than Bitcoin Core using `-assumevalid`.
- Libbitcoin uses an event-based, asynchronous system and relational database to optimize block validation and performance.
- Despite lacking full DoS protection and using an outdated libsecp, Libbitcoin showcases innovative efficiency in blockchain management.

active_posts.title: LNHANCE bips and implementation
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's protocol may add features enhancing Lightning Network and future developments.
- Proposed features include BIP119 and new opcodes to enable advanced conditions on Bitcoin outputs.
- These enhancements aim to improve Bitcoin's scalability, privacy, and financial innovation potential.

today_in_history_posts.title: New BIP: Hardfork warning system
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- This BIP proposes a hardfork warning system via consensus rule changes.
- The system aims to alert users and miners of potential hardforks impacting token value.
- It detects various hardfork scenarios but can't assure against permanent forks.

today_in_history_posts.title: LN without SegWit: less efficient or less secure?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The writer questions SegWit's impact on Lightning Network's feasibility.
- They express interest in LN's level 2, noting its efficiency and security concerns.
- They inquire if outsourcing channel monitoring could mitigate level 2's security issues.

today_in_history_posts.title: Lamport signatures and other CAT tricks
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The correspondence analyzes a blockchain script for processing signature data, questioning its viability.
- It discusses integrating quantum-resistant signatures in taproot and the feasibility of a relevant soft fork.
- The script uses a complex witness structure for data integrity and prepares for quantum threats.
